body: You have a primary key defined and you get the error `Duplicate entry '0' for key 'PRIMARY'`(for your second entry), since it's empty. Use an auto-increment value for your PK.

PK has AUTO_INCREMENT, looks like this is issue in generated SQL query.
When I set any of attributes it works, this error appears only when I try to save an emtpy model.

Following also works
`
INSERT INTO `items` VALUES();
`
It just create new record in DB with all fields NULL and auto incremented field `id`
Can you show the schema of the table?

Hmmm, I do not get an error when using 

    INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (DEFAULT)

when I have a primary key. 

I only can reproduce the error you mentioned in the first comment, when **not** having a PK and a default value of `0`, can you confirm that? What happens when you execute the insert statement on a table with auto-increment PK?

Thanks for posting in our issue tracker.
In order to properly assist you, we need additional information:

- When does the issue occur?
- What do you see?
- What was the expected result?
- Can you supply us with a stacktrace? (optional)
- Do you have exact code to reproduce it? Maybe a PHPUnit tests that fails? (optional)

Thanks!

_This is an automated comment, triggered by adding the label `status:need more info`._

I just recreate table and try again

```sql
CREATE TABLE `items` (
  `id` int(11) NOT NULL,
  `field1` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci DEFAULT NULL,
  `field2` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci DEFAULT NULL,
  `field3` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci DEFAULT NULL,
  `comment` text COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_unicode_ci;

ALTER TABLE `items`
  ADD PRIMARY KEY (`id`);

ALTER TABLE `items`  MODIFY `id` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT;

```

First execution 
```
INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (DEFAULT);
```
is Ok.  Row with (0, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL) was inserted
Second execution of 
```
INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (DEFAULT);
```
gives same error  - #1062 - Duplicate entry '0' for key 'PRIMARY'

But when I execute 
```
INSERT INTO `items` VALUES ();
```
row is successfuly inserted and `id` is auto incremented. so I have rows 
```
0, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
1, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
2, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
```



(Edit!) Also query


~~INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (DEFAULT);~~
```
INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (NULL);
``` 
works fine


Note that I have enabled
```
SET SQL_MODE = "NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO";
```

I guess this is MySQL bug (clinch?). Default _non-null_ value for `int` type is `0` and in case of autoincremented column it works as _magic_ number (together with _null_) and produces next number in sequence - but with `NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO` you explicitly tell it to treat `0` as it is so it can not autoincrement.

I found it reported as a bug [here](https://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=42270) (9 years ago ðŸ™„ )...
Thanks @bizley . Looks very similar. So, because this is probably MySQL bug maybe it is good to create workaround ?
I don't get why you're successfully executing `INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (DEFAULT);` while similar SQL generated by Yii fails.
Isn't this the case where only first one is ok and all following are not?
If it fails with SQL then I don't see how we can provide workaround.

Only first execuiton of  `INSERT INTO items(id) VALUES (DEFAULT);` is Ok, if table does not have PK id == 0
As workaround I suggest pass NULL instead of DEFAULT  (only for PK), because following query works fine:
```
INSERT INTO `items` (`id`) VALUES (NULL);
```
